questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following deficiencies would you suspect in a patient with acute retrobulbar 
neuritis?
questions.explanation:
Vitamin B1 deficiency can cause acute retrobulbar neuritis. Nutritional optic neuropathy is characterized by bilateral, symmetric, cecocentral scotomas and 
disturbance of color vision. Fundus morphology is usually normal. Deficiencies in the following vitamins are primarily responsible for the damage caused to the optic 
nerve: B1 (thiamine), B6 (pyridoxine), B9 (folic acid), and B12 (cobalamin). These vitamins are 
cofactors for many metabolic reactions and their deficiency leads to toxic byproduct accumulation 
within cells, which inhibits the electron transport chain and depresses mitochondrial function. 
Depletion of ATP leads to nerve dysfunction and eventual nerve death. Chronic alcohol abuse is a commonly associated risk factor and a cause of malnourishment.

Question 2: During a community outreach program in a rural area, you come across a girl with a 
conjunctival lesion as shown in the image. According to the WHO grading, which grade does 
this child falls under?
questions.explanation: The given image shows Bitot’s spot, which is seen in the X1B stage of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.question: Question 3: In which of the following conditions will Koplik’s spots and conjunctivitis be seen together?
questions.explanation: Koplik’s spots are seen in measles.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with an extremely painful right 
foot. He stated that he had an alcohol binge the previous night. On examination, the right 
first metatarsophalangeal joint is red, swollen, and extremely tender to palpation. Which of 
the following ocular conditions is not associated with his underlying condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute gout. Glaucoma is not a known association of 
acute gout. Ocular manifestations seen in acute gout are episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis. Ocular structures 
have a relatively poor solvent ability, in addition to lower temperatures. Therefore, they are 
predisposed to tophi deposition. As a result of urate deposits, crystal-induced inflammation of the 
affected tissue is responsible for causing episcleritis, scleritis, and uveitis. 592 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Where is snow flake cataract seen?
questions.explanation: Snowflake cataract is seen in diabetes mellitus. Ocular manifestations in diabetes mellitus • Xanthelasma • Telangiectasia • Subconjunctival hemorrhage • Punctuate keratopathy • Descemet’s folds • Rubeosis iridis • Snow-flake cataract • Vitreous hemorrhage • Diabetic retinopathy • Neovascular glaucoma • Recurrent hordeola • Dry eye • Tractional retinal detachment • Diabetic maculopathy • Papillopathy • Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.explanation: Oil droplet cataract is seen in galactosemia. Characteristic associations are: • Diabetes - Snowflake cataract • Wilson’s disease - Sunflower cataract • Homocystinuria - Bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens

questions.question:
Question 7: A 10-year-old girl with neurological manifestations was referred from the pediatric OPD. Her 
ocular examination findings is as given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the Kayser–Fleisher (KF) ring, which is a characteristic finding of Wilson’s 
disease. KF ring consists of the deposition of copper in the Descemet membrane of the cornea. The rings 
are usually golden-brown and are visible only under the slit-lamp. They do not impair vision. They 593 
Sold by @itachibot disappear on treatment with anti-copper drugs and reappear with disease progression. They are 
a characteristic sign of Wilson’s disease but are not pathognomonic. They can also be seen in: • Primary biliary cholangitis • Primary sclerosing cholangitis • Cholestasis. Sunflower cataract is a rare finding of Wilson's disease. It occurs due to the deposition of copper 
in the centre of the lens. It consists of a greenish central opacity with spoke-like radial opacities 
and is visible only under the slit-lamp. It is also seen in chalcosis (deposition of intraocular 
copper-containing foreign body). The image given below shows a sunflower cataract:

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following conditions can occur as an ocular manifestation in a patient with 
dengue?
questions.explanation:
Cataract is not an ocular manifestation of dengue. Dengue has varied manifestations, in different organ systems, mainly of inflammation and 
bleeding. Until recently, apart from retro-orbital pain, eye involvement was not recognized as a 
common feature of dengue infection. Potential pathogenic mechanisms include a direct viral effect 
on the eye, an immune-mediated vasculitis, and/or a variety of secondary effects related to 
dengue-induced vascular leakage and hemostatic derangements. Ocular manifestations of dengue: • Typically, patients complain of painless visual impairment within 1 week from illness onset, 
often around the time of the platelet nadir. • Conjunctival injection and subconjunctival hemorrhage. • Complications such as retinal hemorrhage, retinal edema, macular ischemia, macular edema, 
vitreous hemorrhage, vitritis, and optic neuritis or papillitis 595 
Sold by @itachibot • Depending on the severity of the ocular lesion, gradual improvement in vision occurs over 
several weeks, although in rare cases permanent visual impairment may result.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine 
stain on the right side of her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a 
leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying 
condition? 588 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture of a young child presenting with unilateral port wine stain in the region 
of trigeminal nerve supply and leptomeningeal angioma as seen on MRI is indicative of 
Sturge-Webber syndrome (SWS). Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of SWS. Sturge weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder(phakomatoses) that is characterized by 
unilateral capillary malformation at the region of trigeminal supply known as port wine stain or 
nevus flammeus, ipsilateral diffuse cavernous hemangioma of the choroid and ipsilateral 
leptomeningeal hemangiomatosis, which causes seizures and mental retardation. Ocular manifestation of SWS include: • Glaucoma - most common ocular manifestation. It develops anywhere between infancy to 
adulthood. When developed in infancy it presents as buphthalmos. • Diffuse choroidal hemangioma • Serous retinal detachment • Visual field defects- homonymous hemianopia due to the leptomeningeal hemangiomas affecting 
the optic tract or occipital lobe. • Heterochromia of the iris • Episcleral and conjunctival lesions Option A: Uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue of the eyes. It can be associated with a 
number of systemic conditions such as sarcoidosis, behcet's disease, ankylosing spondylitis, 
reiter's syndrome,Toxoplasmosis and Posner–Schlossman syndrome (PSS). Option B: Retinitis pigmentosa is an inherited or acquired pigmentatory retinal dystrophy 
affecting the rods more. The earliest manifestation is worsening of night blindness which 
gradually progresses to tunnel vision and ultimately loss of central vision. The classic triad of 
findings in RP comprises bone-spicule retinal pigmentation, arteriolar attenuation and waxy disc 
pallor. Systemic Associations of RP include: • Laurence-Moon-Biedl syndrome • Cockayne's syndrome • Refsum's syndrome • Usher's syndrome • Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome The below given image shows the classical triad findings of Retinitis pigmentosa. 596 
Sold by @itachibot Option C:Keratitis is the inflammation of cornea which is characterised by corneal edema, cellular 
infiltration and ciliary congestion. It can be either infectious or non-infectious in nature which 
includes allergic keratitis, neurotrophic keratitis, exposure keratitis and peripheral ulcerative 
keratopathies such as Rosacea keratitis and Mooren's ulcer.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 70-year-old man presented with complaints of diminution of vision in both eyes for the last 
6 - 8 months. On examination, bilateral cataracts were seen. Incidentally, you also note iris 
pearls. Which of the following conditions should you suspect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Iris pearls are pearly-white nodules seen on the iris in leprosy. They are asymptomatic, 0.3 to 1.0 mm in diameter, dull yellowish-white in colour, and are seen at 
an early stage of the disease. It is not associated with any inflammatory changes in the anterior 
chamber. Histologically, it consists of lepromatous bacilli packed within mononuclear cells or 
acid-fast material with accompanying foreign body reaction. Inside the eye, leprosy bacilli 
preferentially lodge in the iris and ciliary body, due to the relatively cooler temperatures and high 
vascularity.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presents with areas of yellowish papular skin lesions and redundant and inelastic 
folds of skin on the neck and thighs. Which of the following ocular findings is not seen in this 
disease?
questions.explanation:
The given case suggests a diagnosis of pseudoxanthoma elasticum. Arterial macroaneurysm is not 
a feature of this disease. Ocular findings in pseudoxanthoma elasticum: • Blue sclera • Angioid streaks • Optic nerve head drusen • “Peau-d’orange” appearance of the retina • Choroidal neovascularization 597 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: An elderly patient admitted with multiple comorbidities in the ICU, developed exposure 
keratitis and ulceration. An ophthalmology opinion was sought. Incidentally, on fundoscopy, 
the resident found the following picture. What is this most likely due to?
questions.explanation:
The given image suggests a diagnosis of proliferative diabetic retinopathy. The hallmark of Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) is neovascularization. Abnormal new 
vessel formation, which occurs on the inner (vitreous) surface of the retina and may extend into 
the vitreous cavity, can cause vitreous haemorrhage. Neovascularization is often accompanied by 
pre-retinal fibrous tissue, which, along with the vitreous, can contract, resulting in traction retinal 
detachment. In addition, tiny microaneurysms can also be seen.

questions.question:
Question 14: In patients with a long-standing history of Crohn's disease, which of the following ocular 
complications is the most likely to develop?
questions.explanation: The most common ocular manifestation of Crohn’s disease is episcleritis. Uveitis is associated with both Ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.

Question 15: 590 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with a history of decreased vision was evaluated with fundus fluorescein 
angiography. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image depicts neovascularization, which is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic 
retinopathy. Dye can be seen leaking through abnormal neovascular fronds. Both neovascularization of the disc 
(NVD), as well as neovascularization elsewhere (NVE i.e., 2 DD away from the optic disc 
margin), are seen. The treatment available for proliferative diabetic retinopathy is photocoagulation of the ischaemic 
areas to reduce the metabolic demand and decrease or prevent the release of vasoproliferative 
factors. 598 
Sold by @itachibot Community Ophthalmology
